channel.title: Learning the Java language
channel.description:
Hey,
I've been around here for some months, learned a few things, made some friends, and enjoying it so far.
I have seen people here coding like it's nothing, they look at the 'issue', think a bit, then solve it without any help at all. What I wonder is, what did they do to achieve that?
Basically, I have absolute zero knowledge about Java, that's why I am here, to learn.
My goal is to work on my own RSPS someday. And with work I don't mean the easy things like changing coordinates, adding shops, npc's, small features, etc. which I can do now.
I would like to do the big stuff, the coding itself.
So, to all the experienced coders here: What did you do when you were at my position: No knowledge of Java in any way, what did you do to learn, where did you start?
If anyone could give me some tips, or even give me advice on where to start, I'd really appreciate!
Summer holidays are coming and I would like to know alot at the end or during summer. Time is not a problem, I have time enough and I'm willing to learn, no matter how hard it is, or no matter how many people seem to give up at some point.
Best regards,
Derpington

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

You make it sound like Mopar is a place for people that already know everything, and the ‘less experienced’ like me are not allowed here. I’m pretty sure that one of the main points of this website was to learn from eachother. And what do you mean with bad habits? If you took the time to post such comment, you might aswell give some advice on what’s wrong in your opinion instead of just saying I am already doing it the wrong way.

By “bad habit” I guess he was talking about the programming style. You might be interested in reading this: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/codeconv-138413.html. Provided you’re code is readable and consistent in style, it’s not really a problem, but then again sticking to conventions that are used by many people could increase readability. Another thing is that it’s a poor example. Write something more meaningful. I can’t comment on how useful Bucky’s tutorials are since I haven’t seen them, but I suggest using additional resources to learn Java. reallybigindex, for example.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

If I were to give you one recommendation it’d be just to think of a project that you’re interested in and won’t drop it with no reason. Just go for it and whenever you get stuck just refer to relative documentation and google for support, then read it and fully understand what you’re implementing.

Also don’t forget you won’t just pick up the language instantly, stick with it, learn it properly and don’t over challenge yourself straight away as it’s a nice way to loose interest.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:10, topic:446221”][quote author=Derpington link=topic=549080.msg4027274#msg4027274 date=1340441378]
You make it sound like Mopar is a place for people that already know everything, and the ‘less experienced’ like me are not allowed here. I’m pretty sure that one of the main points of this website was to learn from eachother. And what do you mean with bad habits? If you took the time to post such comment, you might aswell give some advice on what’s wrong in your opinion instead of just saying I am already doing it the wrong way.
[/quote]
Well, you make a valid point when you say “you take the time to post such comment~”, but let me remind you, I have no desire to correct your bad habits. Quite frankly, and simply put, I have no fucks to give about you, your programming ability, or your server.

ps it is for people that know everything, you’re not welcome. Fuck off outta here[/quote]Hey, shut up.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @sssylasss sssylasss
item.description:
@sssylasss wrote:

watch the standford videos on youtube, they are pretty good, also go through the official oracle tutorials they go from a to z.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

The way I learned was almost entirely through experience. I started writing C++ when I was 11 with my cousin using a really old Visual C++ IDE, and then I got into RSPS. I noticed Java was a lot like C++ in the way it ended “lines” with semicolons, used parenthesis, used curly brackets, had very similar type names, etc… I didn’t understand half of the stuff I was doing, but I’d still add content from tutorials and looking at what the server already had, like how adding a shop usually required 3 lines and a “wanneShop” check. Over time, I learned why things happened and was eventually able to write my own code. I never read a single tutorial on learning a language.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @frozon566 frozon566
item.description:
@frozon566 wrote:

Bucky on youtube teaches Java pretty well and without complicating it with those bigwords.

Here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hl-zzrqQoSE&list=PLFE2CE09D83EE3E28&index=1&feature=plpp_video

Thats the first video to a 87 video playlist that walks you through the basics of Java programming

If you look around on his channel he has an intermediate playlist along with a game development playlist using the Slick library all in Java.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Derpington, post:1, topic:446252”]I’m currently at college, doing IT, Networkmanagement. We do have a programming course, but after summer I’m entering the second year so It’s too late to change now. I’ve read quite alot about the index already, thank you for that!

Also, I would like to make some sort of ‘remake’ in the future… Like, you start of @ tut island, you have to make your way through, etc. The main thing I want to focus on is making dialogues and stuff, cause i’d love to make (working) quests.

Apart of the tips you guys gave me, is it an option to start off with some client and source, and then look into the code itself to see what everything does, etc. ? I think i’ll understand it better that way and it keeps me motivated. But maybe that’s not a good idea after all, that’s why I am asking right now :>

I thought I would get flamed hard for this post, but I’m glad I didn’t. :)[/quote]
the best way to learn is first learning the theory and then implementing it

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

If you have AP/IB Computer Science at your school, take it. I have never received that opportunity; if your school offers that, I highly recommend that you take it.

It’s summertime now, if your parents have extra money, attend a programming camp. Otherwise, take an online class.

And here is the really big index incase you need it: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reallybigindex.html

Read full topic

item.title: Learning the Java language
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

if you have absolutely no experience in programming, try picking up Python as it has easy syntax. after getting comfortable you can start learning java syntax and the api - you can do this by using the reallybigindex. eventually, you’re going to want to learn OO techniques to create robust frameworks.

Read full topic
